figure_1: Within-person (left column) and between-person (right column) associations between morning negative affect and later-day smoking urges (top row), and later-day smoking behavior (bottom row). Light gray lines (left column) show the range of individual differences in the extent of the within-person associations. Results indicated evidence of credible associations for the top left panel, top right panel and bottom left panel.
figure_2: Within-person (left column) and between-person (right column) associations between morning positive affect and later-day smoking behavior (top row), and between morning negative affect and later-day smoking behavior (bottom row). Light gray lines (left column) show the range of individual differences in the extent of the within-person associations. Results indicated evidence of credible associations for the top left panel and top right panel.
figure_3: Power under different random-effect SDs for the multilevel logistic regression model. Correlation between the random intercept and random slope is set as zero for conditions in these two plots.
figure_4: Power under different fixed-effect intercepts for the multilevel logistic regression model. The top two plots are with medium-to-large random effect SDs (SD3) and the bottom two with small random-effect SD (SD1).
figure_5: Power under different correlation between random effects for the multilevel logistic regression model. The top two plots are with medium-to-large random effect SDs (SD3) and the bottom two with medium random-effect SD (SD2).
figure_6: Power under different random-effect SDs for the multilevel linear regression model. Correlation between the random intercept and random slope is set as zero for conditions in these two plots.
figure_7: Power under different random-effect SDs for the multilevel linear regression model. Correlation between the random intercept and random slope is set as zero for conditions in these two plots.
